questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came with complaints of fever, cough, multiple joint pain, and painful rashes on the leg as shown below. Chest x-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary biopsy showed non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A female patient with fever, arthritis, lesions suggestive of erythema nodosum, and chest x-ray of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with biopsy showing non-caseating granuloma are suggestive of Lofgren's syndrome.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. It is more often seen in women. 

There are two syndromes that are associated with sarcoidosis are: 

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis may also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is the bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Other manifestations of sarcoidosis include: 

  • Ophthalmologic - anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision
  • Neurological - myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis
  • Dermatological - maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include:

  • Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated
  • BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Gallium scan shows the following signs:
    • Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands 
    • Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes 
  • Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas along with features of sarcoidosis is confirmatory.
  • PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease

Other options:

Option A: Heerfordt–Waldenstrom syndrome also known as uveoparotid fever is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis characterized by fever, parotid enlargement, facial palsy, and anterior uveitis.

Option C: Loeffler's syndrome is transient pulmonary eosinophilia which occurs in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs. Most commonly, it is seen in roundworm (Ascaris species) infection.

Option D: Sweet syndrome is also known as febrile neutrophilic dermatosis. It is characterized by the presence of WBCs in the lower dermis. It is mostly seen in neutropenic patients with malignancies such as acute myeloid leukemia.

Related Pearl: Named lung diseases

Bagassosis

 Pneumoconiosis due to sugarcane
Byssinosis (brown lung disease/ Monday fever) Pneumoconiosis due to cotton fiber
Farmer’s lung Pneumoconiosis due to Thermophilic actinomycetes
Bird Fancier’s lung Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by bird droppings
Chalicosis (flint disease)  In stonecutters, due to inhalation of fine particles of stone
Caplan’s syndrome  RA + pneumoconiosis
Lofgren's syndrome An acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy
Bornholm’s disease (epidemic pleurodynia) associated with Coxsackie B virus

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, bluish discoloration was noted over the left 9th and 10th rib area. On asking the patient to take a deep breath, he winced due to pain in the left shoulder region.  Identify the most likely sign elicited here.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette refers to pain over the left shoulder tip on inspiration. This is known as Kehr's sign, which is seen in splenic trauma.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament, leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to a positive Kehr's sign.

Initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) to explore for free fluid.

In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I

Subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area)

Or

Laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II

Subcapsular hematoma (10–50% of surface area)

Or

Laceration, 1–3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Subcapsular hematoma >50% of surface area or expanding

  • ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding

Or
Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
Or
A hilar vascular injury with complete devascularization.

 

The management approach depends on the grade of injury:

Grade I and Grade II injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically stable so they can be managed non-operatively.  It includes adequate bed rest, serial abdominal CECT's monitoring of vitals has to be done. If any shift to a high-grade injury, angioembolization can be done.

If the angioembolization fails, a spleen-sparing technique called splenorraphy can be done.

Grade IV and V injuries: Usually, they are hemodynamically unstable so splenectomy is done.

Grade III injury: If they are hemodynamically stable, they are managed as grades I and II while those are hemodynamically unstable, they are managed as grades IV and V.

Other options:

Option A- Courvoisier's sign is palpable gall bladder in the presence of jaundice due to periampullary carcinoma.

Option B- Cullen's sign is dark bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.

Option C- Ballance sign is a sign of splenic injury. Persistent dullness on the left side of the abdomen due to early coagulation of blood from the spleen is a positive sign. Shifting dullness can be present on the right side.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented to the OPD with fever, dysuria, and frequent micturition. Urine analysis showed pus cells. Gram staining shows gram-negative rods and culture on MacConkey agar shows non-lactose fermenting colonies. The test for the presence of phenylalanine deaminase gives the result shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of urinary tract infection, with a gram-negative rod forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and the image of a positive phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction are suggestive of Proteus infection.

The phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction is a characteristic feature that distinguishes Proteus from other enterobacteria. All members of the Proteus tribe have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. Phenyl pyruvic acid imparts a green color. The test is given below:


Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

Non-lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S Sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

Other options:

Klebsiella (Option A) and Enterobacter (Option D) are lactose-fermenters on MacConkey's medium. Serratia (Option C) is a late lactose fermenter.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus. His father suffered a similar condition and passed away last year. What is the most likely electron microscopic picture of his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette with a positive family history is suggestive of Alport Syndrome. The most likely electron microscopy of his renal biopsy is the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Other options:

Option A: Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases. 

Option C: Epithelial crescent formation is seen in crescentic RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis etc. Features include oliguria and other signs of nephritic syndrome.

Option D: Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is caused due to immune complex deposition of streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies. Clinical features include malaise, oliguria, and hematuria around 1-2 weeks after a streptococcal infection. The urine is typically described as smoky or cola-colored urine. 

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

 Focal mesangial proliferative glomerulo-nephritis; mesangial widening  IgA ± IgG, IgM, and C3 in mesangium Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits 

Alport syndrome

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte 

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

 Negative 

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3, C1q, C4 deposits 

IgG deposits

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative  pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3 deposits;

No C1q and C4 deposits

No IgG deposits

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

 

Related Pearl: Sites of Deposits in Glomerular diseases

Subepithelial
  • Membranous nephropathy (epimembranous)
  • PSGN
Intramembranous
  • Dense deposit disease (MPGN type II)

  • MPGN Type I

MPGN: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

PSGN: Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis 

FSGS: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

RPGN: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis 

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker with uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus, not on medication, was planned to undergo elective appendicectomy. He was brought for a pre-anesthetic checkup. In which ASA-PS class would you place this patient?

ASA-PS: American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status
questions.solution:
A patient who is a chronic smoker with uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus is placed under ASA-PS class III.

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification system was developed to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical comorbidities.

Perioperative risks cannot be predicted with this classification system alone, but when used with other factors (eg: type of surgery, level of deconditioning), it can help to predict perioperative risks.

This system assigns patients into 6 classes—class I to class VI. An additional class E denotes an emergency surgical procedure.

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with complaints of purplish itchy lesions on his skin as shown below. On examination, thin white lines were present on the surface of the lesions. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C infection 3 years back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a purplish papular itchy lesion on the skin with Wickham's striae and a history of hepatitis C, which is suggestive of lichen planus.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. 

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles. There is an increased risk of developing lichen planus in individuals with a history of hepatitis C.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are the buccal mucosa and the tongue. Nail involvement can be seen as the thinning of the nail plate leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines, and linear depressions.

Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have a sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Corticosteroids are the mainstay of lichen planus treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease. A typical bilateral symmetrical skin eruption consists of macules with a collarette scale in the periphery. It is seen in a characteristic "Christmas tree pattern" over the back and if a lesion on the upper chest may have a V-shaped pattern. The most common persisting sign is the oval salmon herald patch.

Option B- Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin. It is seen particularly over the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region as erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales. On removal of these scales pinpoint bleeding is seen. This is called as Auspitz sign.

Option C- Reiter's syndrome is also called reactive arthritis. Conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis after a genitourinary or gastrointestinal tract infection is the classic triad of reactive arthritis. A common dermal manifestation of reactive arthritis is keratoderma blenorrhagicum.

Related Pearl: Papulosquamous Disorders

  • Lichen planus
  • Psoriasis
  • Parapsoriasis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris
  • Pityriasis rosea
  • Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Drug Reactions
  • Reiter’s disease
  • Eczema
  • Neoplasms (Mycosis fungoides, Squamous cell carcinoma,  Bowen’s disease)
  • Tinea infections

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented with lethargy, diarrhea, and darkening around the eyes. On examination, his blood pressure was elevated and a mass was palpated in the abdomen.  A biopsy from the mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with a mass in the abdomen, diarrhea, ecchymosis, hypertension, histopathology showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes is suggestive of neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain that originates from neural crest cells. The most common cause of familial predisposition is the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene mutation. It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Patients present with a mass in the abdomen, ecchymosis or proptosis due to secondary lesions in the periorbital region, and elevated blood pressure due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood.

In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. In children, neuroblastoma mostly arises from the adrenal medulla. On transsection, it is composed of grey-tan tissue with hemorrhage and areas of necrosis and calcification. A biopsy of the tumor gives a pathological diagnosis. Histology shows small, round blue cells with dark nuclei, scanty cytoplasm, and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. CT or MRI to assess the mass and secondaries. The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

The image below shows a typical Homer-wright pseudorosette is seen in which tumor cells are arranged concentrically with a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material:

Other options:

Option A: Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically, it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells that form trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver. The image below shows the histology of hepatoblastoma, which shows proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial cells.

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a mesenchymal malignant tumor. Histologically, it comprises sheets of primitive round cells with skeletal muscle differentiation. The image below shows the histology of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma and sheets of primitive round cells.

Option C: Nephroblastoma, also known as Wilms tumor, is the most common primary renal tumor in childhood. Histologically, it shows the classic triphasic pattern composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking. Detailed history revealed regression of language milestones. Microcephaly was noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly.

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition predominantly seen in girls. Under the international classification of diseases, the tenth revision falls under pervasive development disorder. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, 5th edition (DSM-5) considers it an autism spectrum disorder, though there are marked differences between them.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but growth begins to decelerate between the ages of 6 months to 1 year. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Options A&D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development. 

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There are marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

Related Pearl: Autism Spectrum Disorder

 

  Autism Rett syndrome Asperger syndrome Heller syndrome
Onset Before 3 years After 5 months After 3 years After 2 years
Gender predilection Boys Girls Boys Boys
Intellectual disability Present in 30% of the cases Present Absent Present
Language Mostly poor Mostly poor Normal Mostly poor
Remarks ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

 ---

Normal head circumference at birth.

Regression of milestones

NOTE: Rett's syndrome has been removed from DSM-5 because it was found to have a clear genetic basis.

 
DSM - 4
DSM - 5
Change in Classification 
Pervasive Developmental disorders
Autistic Spectrum Disorder
Number of Domains 
3 domains
2 domains
Impairment in social interaction and communication 
 

  • Delay or total lack of development of spoken language

  • Stereotyped and repetitive use of language

  • Impairment in the use of multiple nonverbal behaviors

  • Failure to develop peer relationships

  • Lack of social or emotional reciprocity
 
 

  • Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors

  • Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships

  • Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity 
Repetitive and restricted
interests/behaviors 
 
  • Stereotyped and repetitive motor mannerisms

  • Inflexible adherence to specific, nonfunctional routines

  • Persistent preoccupation with parts of an object
 

  • Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements

  • Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines

  • Highly restricted, fixated interests.

  • Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input

questions.text: On suspecting an ulnar nerve injury, the clinician tried to elicit a test as shown below. The test he was trying to elicit is _____.
questions.solution:
The test clinician trying to elicit was Froment's test.

In Froment's test or Book Test, the patient is asked to grasp a book or a sheet of paper between the thumb and index finger. Due to weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of the thumb is lost. When asked to hold a book, the patient tries to hold the book by using the flexor pollicis longus muscle instead of the adductor, this produces flexion at the interphalangeal joint as shown in the above image.

The ulnar nerve arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus. Motor branches of ulnar nerve supplies:

  • flexor carpi ulnaris
  • medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
  • hypothenar muscles
  • adductor pollicis
  • all interossei
  • medial two lumbricals

Injury to the Ulnar nerve:

  High lesion
(Elbow) 		 Low lesion 
(Wrist) 
Site of injury

Fracture or dislocation of the medial epicondyle

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Wrist laceration or Injury to the distal third of the forearm

Guyon's canal syndrome
Motor loss

Partial claw-hand deformity

Hypothenar & interosseous wasting

Loss of:

• Abduction & adduction of fingers
(Card test - Positive)
• Adduction of thumb
(Froment sign- Positive)
• Flexion of MCP joints

Weakness of wrist flexion (radial deviation)

Complete claw-hand deformity
(more pronounced)

Hypothenar & interosseous wasting

Loss of:

• Abduction & adduction of fingers
(Card test - Positive)
• Adduction of thumb
(Froment sign- Positive)
Sensory loss

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

No sensory loss over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand

Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

 

Other tests used in ulnar nerve injuries include:

Card test (Option C): Examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers of the patient. He asks to hold it tightly as possible while he tries to pull the card back. Due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles patient is unable to hold a card between the fingers.

Egawa's test (Option A) is for the dorsal interossei (abductors) of the middle finger which is supplied by the ulnar nerve. With palm kept flat on a table, the patient is asked to move is his middle finger sideways. Due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger are weak.

Other options:

Option B: Oschners clasp test is done for the median nerve injury. On suspecting an injury, the patient is asked to clasp his hand, the index finger fails to flex (pointing index). This is because flexors of index fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus) are supplied by the median nerve.

Related Pearl: Upper limb nerve integrity tests

 Nerve

    Test

    Muscle
 Ulnar   nerve

 1.Book test

 2.Card test

 3.Froment's sign

 4.Egawa test

 1.Adductor   pollicis

 2.Palmar   interossei

 3.Flexor pollicis   substitutes for   adductor pollicis

 Median   nerve

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of sexual assault followed by amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test was positive. Which of the following is the most likely maturation index of her vaginal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The most likely maturation index of vaginal epithelium in a pregnant woman is 0/95/5.

The maturation index is also known as the karyopyknotic index. It is the ratio of mature squamous (superficial) cells to the intermediate and parabasal cells, expressed in percentage. It is expressed in three numbers expressing each of these cell types in percentages, in the format of parabasal cells/intermediate cells/superficial cells. Parabasal cells are round small and basophilic. Intermediate cells are transparent and basophilic. Superficial cells are thin, large, and acidophilic.

Estrogen produces superficial cell maturation; progesterone, androgen, corticosteroids, and pregnancy produce intermediate cell maturation, whereas lack of any hormonal activity produces parabasal cell dominance.

In pregnancy, the most likely maturation index is 0/95/5. During pregnancy, if the ratio of superficial cells is more than 10 percent it denotes the progesterone deficiency.

The most likely shift of the maturation index from birth to menopause is:

 Stage           Maturation index
(parabasal/intermediate/superficial)
At birth  0/95/5
Childhood    80/20/0
Reproductive period
Preovulatory  0/40/60
Mild secretory  0/70/30
Pregnancy  0/95/5
Postpartum    100/0/0   
Postmenopausal  100/0/0

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. 

The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain  (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics.

Option A-  Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into the meatus causing otorrhea.

Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.

Related Pearl: Signs of impending complication in attico-antral disease

Sign

Complication

Pain

Extradural, Perisinus, Brain abscess

Vertigo

Labyrinthine fistula, Labyrinthitis

Persistent headache

Intracranial complication

Facial weakness

Facial Paralysis

Fever

Intracranial Complication

Nausea/Vomiting

Intracranial Complication

Neck rigidity

Meningitis

Diplopia

Gradenigo’s syndrome/ Petrous apecitis

Ataxia

Labyrinthitis, Cerebellar abscess

Abscess around ear

Mastoiditis

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. The most likely primary cause is
questions.solution:
The most likely primary cause of an enlarged inguinal lymph node is anal cancer. 

Lymphatics from the anal canal distal to the dentate line (anal margin) drains into the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, anal cancer arising distal to dentate line can cause enlarged inguinal lymph nodes. Lymphatics proximal to the dentate line (anal canal) drains into internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

Option A: In testicular cancer, lymphatic spread occurs to the paraaortic lymph nodes.

Option C: In sigmoid colon cancer, lymphatic spread occurs to the regional lymph node and then to the central lymph node.

Option D: In prostate cancer, lymphatic spread occurs to the:

  • Lymph nodes beside the internal iliac vein and in the hollow of the sacrum
  • External iliac lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which vitamin, when infused in supraphysiological doses, causes macular edema and macular cysts?
questions.solution:
Macular cysts and edema may develop in patients due to the infusion of supraphysiological doses of vitamin B3 (niacin toxicity).

The toxic effects of niacin include:

  • Flushing associated with skin dryness, itching, paresthesia, and headache is seen. These effects may be seen with even a low dose of 30mg/day. Pre-medication with aspirin alleviates these symptoms as these symptoms are mediated by prostaglandins.
  • Macular edema and macular cysts
  • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
  • Hepatic toxicity presents as jaundice with elevated AST and ALT levels.
  • Fulminant hepatitis requiring liver transplantation.
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore. 

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • The general morphology of ticks includes an oval-shaped body, four pairs of legs, and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in the front. Absent.
Head Situated at the anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body (ventrally). Not visible from above.
Eggs Several hundreds or thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Cannot withstand starvation; feed night and day. Can withstand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Soft tick is a reservoir for Q fever and a vector for relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, and toxaphene. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Arthropod Disease transmitted
Anopheles mosquito Malaria, Filariasis
Culex mosquito Bancroftian filariasis, Japenese encephalitis, West nile fever, Viral arthritis
Aedes mosquito Yellow fever, Dengue, Chikungunya, filariasis, zika
Mansoni Mosquito Filariasis, Chikungunya
Housefly Typhoid and paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar(Visceral Leishmaniasis), oriental sore, Oroya fever, Sandfly fever
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness(African Trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus(Murine Typhus), hymenolepis diminuta
Black fly(Simulium) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug(Kissing bug/triatominae) Chagas disease(American Trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick (Ixodes species) Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, viral hemorrhagic fever,(e.g. Kyasanur forest disease), tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, lyme disease
Soft Tick (Argas species) Q fever, relapsing fever, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) (can be casued by hard tick as well)
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus, Rickettsial pox
Itch mites Scabies
Cyclops Guinea-worm disease, fish tapeworm (D. latum)
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrance, Jiggar, Chigoe flea)  Tungiasis, Ulcer in the feetnails

Related Pearl: Bioterrorism Agents

questions.text: An employee working in a multinational company was found guilty of manipulating the details of financial transactions and forging new cheques in his name. He can be punished under which of the following sections of IPC?
questions.solution:
In the case given above, the employee can be charged with forgery. Section 336 BNS (463 IPC) deals with forgery.

According to this, one who makes any false documents or false electronic record or part of a document or electronic record, with an intention to cause damage to the public or to any person, commits forgery.

Other options:

Option A- Section 229 BNS (193 IPC) deals with punishment for perjury.

Option B- Section 106(1) BNS (304A IPC) deals with causing death by negligence.

Option D- Section 271 BNS (270 IPC) deals with malignant acts likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man came with complaints of reduced vividness of saturated colors. On examination, he was found to have altered depth perception for moving objects. This phenomenon is due to which of the following condition seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Altered depth perception, especially for moving objects, is known as Pulfrich phenomenon. The given clinical findings of Pulfrich phenomenon and reduced vividness of saturated colors (vivid and intense colors) are suggestive of optic neuritis.

On examination, Pulfrich phenomenon is observed when a small target is oscillated to and fro within the plane facing the patient. He perceives it as moving in an elliptical path.

Pulfrich phenomenon is an indication of nerve dysfunction. It is seen in optic neuritis because there is a delay in visual information reaching the cortex via the affected optic nerve, which results in altered depth perception.

Optic neuritis comprises inflammatory and demyelinating disorders of the optic nerve. Other symptoms of optic neuritis include:

  • Visual loss – monocular, sudden, progressive, and profound (the hallmark of acute optic neuritis) 
  • Lowered dark adaptation
  • Visual obscuration in bright light
  • Reduced vividness of colors
  • Phosphenes – Movement and sound-induced glowing sensations in the eye (phosphenes are the glowing sensation produced by non photic inadequate stimuli)
  • Uhthoff's phenomenon – Transient visual obscuration on exertion and exposure to heat that resolves on resting or moving away from the heat source
  • Pain – Mild dull eye ache. More marked in retrobulbar neuritis. Aggravated by eye movement

Signs of optic neuritis:

  • Marked reduction in visual acuity
  • Impaired color vision
  • Marcus Gunn Pupil indicates the relative afferent pupillary defect, is a diagnostic sign. Can be detected by swinging flashlight test
  • Disc hyperemia with blurred margin
  • Central or centrocaecal scotoma in the visual field (most common field defect in optic neuritis)

Other options:

Option A- Retinitis pigmentosa is a hereditary disorder predominantly affecting photoreceptors. It leads to night blindness and tubular vision.

Option B- Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina proper from the pigment epithelium. It usually presents as floaters in front of the eye and the sensation of flashes of light.

Option D- Vitreous hemorrhage is a disease occurring in the posterior segment of the eye. It usually presents as floaters in front of the eye and loss of vision.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presented with difficulty in urination and back pain. His PSA levels were found to be elevated and the x-ray pelvis revealed two osteoblastic lesions in the bony pelvis. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the given condition?

PSA - Prostate Specific Antigen
questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigations showing elevated PSA osteoblastic lesions in the pelvis are suggestive of metastatic prostate cancer. Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist used in the treatment of prostate cancer.

Androgen deprivation therapy is the primary medical therapy for prostate cancer. The drugs used for this indication are GnRH agonists such as goserelin, buserelin, leuprolide, nafarelin, and triptorelin. The agonist action of the GnRH analogs causes an initial increase in LH, leading to increased testosterone production. This causes a tumor flare. This can be prevented by concomitant administration of an androgen receptor antagonist such as flutamide or bicalutamide.

After the initial period, there is a downregulation of GnRH receptors and changes in the downstream pathways, leading to a decrease in gonadotropins and testosterone (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism). The androgen deprivation therapy with continuous GnRH agonist and an androgen receptor antagonist is as effective as surgical castration in reducing the levels of serum testosterone.

GnRH antagonists such as degarelix can also be used for androgen deprivation therapy. It has the advantage of not having a tumor flare phenomenon. However, because of the long-term safety profile of GnRH agonists, they are the preferred drugs for androgen deprivation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of advanced breast cancer.

Option B: Desogestrel is a synthetic progestin without androgenic activity. It is used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.

Option D: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is a weak inhibitor of the androgen receptor and causes gynecomastia as a common side effect. It has been used in women to treat hirsutism.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient who was a chronic smoker came with complaints of swelling in the lip, as shown below. On examination, an ulcerative mass was seen and a submental lymph node was palpable. Which of the following is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type
Women above 60 years of age are commonly affected
Vermilion border of the upper lip is the common site
Exposure to chemicals like benzene is a common cause

questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of lip cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of lip cancer.

Lip cancer most commonly occurs in men above 50 years of age. Exposure to the sun and smoking are the main risk factors of lip cancer. More than 90% of lip cancers are squamous cell carcinoma.

Most lip cancers occur in the lower lip, followed by the upper lip and commissure. The most common site is the vermilion border of the lower lip. But the commonly occurring cancer in the upper lip is basal cell carcinoma.

Ulcerative lesion on the vermilion border of the lower lip is the most common clinical manifestation. The mass can extend and fix on the underlying bone. There is a loss of sensation on the skin over the chin due to the involvement of mental nerves. Submental and submandibular nodes are frequently involved.

The early-stage disease can be treated by surgery or radiation therapy. Post-surgical irradiation is indicated in advanced-stage disease. For defects of more than one-third of the lip, surgical excision followed by lip augmentation surgery is needed.

questions.text:
An EEG conducted during sleep in a normal individual is given below. Identify the most likely change in neurotransmitters in the highlighted period.

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
In the given EEG, waves highlighted in red show the typical saw-tooth appearance of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. The most likely change in neurotransmitters during this period is an increase in acetylcholine.

The other change in neurotransmitters during REM sleep is a decrease in serotonin and norepinephrine. 

An EEG is a recording that represents the electrical activity of the brain. It is used in localizing neuropathological lesions.

The brainstem ascending arousal system is composed of several groups of neurons like:

  • Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine
  • Raphe nucleus  secretes serotonin
  • Pontine nucleus secretes acetylcholine

During wakefulness, the locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are dominant and the pontine is suppressed. Therefore, when a person is awake the norepinephrine and serotonin are increased and acetylcholine is decreased. There is also decreased GABA and increased histamine during wakefulness.

REM sleep occurs when the pontine nucleus is dominant and locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are suppressed. Therefore acetylcholine is increased and norepinephrine and serotonin are decreased. 

NREM (non-rapid eye movement) sleep occurs when there is suppression of the thalamus and cortex due to an increase in GABA and a decrease in histamine. 

Other options: Increase in serotonin, norepinephrine, and histamine is seen during wakefulness. 

The image given below shows EEG patterns in different stages of sleep.

Related Pearl: Difference between NREM and REM Sleep

Physiological Process

NREM

REM

Brain activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases in motor and sensory areas, while other areas are similar to NREM

Heart rate

Slows from wakefulness

Increases and varies compared to NREM

Blood pressure

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases (up to 30 percent) and varies from NREM

Sympathetic nerve activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases significantly from wakefulness

Muscle tone

Similar to wakefulness

Absent

Blood flow to brain

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases from NREM, depending on brain region

Respiration

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from NREM, but may show brief stoppages; coughing suppressed

Airway resistance

Increases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from wakefulness

Body temperature

Is regulated at lower set point than wakefulness; shivering initiated at lower temperature than during wakefulness

Is not regulated; no shivering or sweating; temperature drifts toward that of the local environment

Sexual arousal

Occurs infrequently

Greater than NREM

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A 60-year-old hypertensive patient, non-compliant with his treatment, suffered an intraparenchymal hemorrhagic stroke one month ago. He undergoes MRI for follow-up. The appearance of the hemorrhage on T1 and T2 weighted MRIs at present, would be respectively?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient had an intraparenchymal stroke one month ago. Hence, the appearance of intraparenchymal hemorrhage on both T1 and T2 weighted MRI is hypointense.

On an MRI, hyperintense refers to a bright or white appearance, while hypointense refers to a darker or black appearance. Isointense means similar color as that of the surrounding brain parenchyma.

The appearance of various stages of intraparenchymal hemorrhage on MRI:

Stage Time Hemoglobin T1 T2
Hyper-acute <24 hours Oxy-hemoglobin Iso Hyper
Acute 1-3 days Deoxy-hemoglobin Iso Hypo
Early subacute 3-7 days Intracellular
Methemoglobin		 Hyper Hypo
Late subacute 7-13 days Extracellular
Methemoglobin		 Hyper Hyper
Chronic >14 days Hemosiderin Hypo Hypo

After 14 days the extracellular blood will be degraded to hemosiderin. Hence, the appearance of the intraparenchymal hemorrhage will be hypointense on both T1 and T2 weighted MRI.
